Award.AwardTitle: Transforming Students' Mathematical Experiences: Advancing Quality Teaching with Reliability at Scale

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project, led by the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching, furthers the reach of the Statway and Quantway Pathways through Networked Improvement Communities (NICs) of colleges and universities. Initial implementation of these pathways has shown significant success rates for developmental math students in only one third of the time typically required for college-level math credit. This project is scaling and sustaining the initiative through the design, development, and improvement of a rigorous Advancing Quality Teaching (AQT) program for faculty. As the Pathways initiative expands beyond those faculty and colleges that collaborated in the original co-development, a much broader range of faculty, including adjuncts, working in varied college work conditions is included. The AQT system is designed to maintain high levels of efficacy as the initiative is taken up more broadly.

The project, with the college and research partners in the Networked Improvement Communities is working towards the following: an experience which introduces new members into the network through a Deep Study of Instruction; Pathways Toolkit of Professional Development Resources; the Advancing Quality Teaching Rubric, a formative tool to guide individual faculty development; an Improvement Science Workshop that introduces faculty to the discipline of improvement science and supports their improvement work in their own classrooms; leadership development to identify and support the project's National Faculty who will take on significant roles in this NIC; and a Regional Infrastructure of lead colleges associated with the National Faculty to provide a local base for the collaborative work of the improvement communities.

The project transforms and elevates developmental math instruction where faculty employ the discipline of improvement science to continuously enhance their teaching within a networked community of researchers and practitioners. It creates a sustainable system for improvement. The Pathways are anchored in ambitious math learning goals and deploy research-based pedagogy to make deeper learning common in classrooms. The project's integration of a Productive Persistence initiative explicitly addresses the many deep-seated psycho-social barriers that students face. The project aims to demonstrate how to learn what works, for whom, and under what conditions and to provide for the spread of this knowledge.

Not only do the project's strategic organization and processes provide for the implementation of the Pathways in other settings, they also provide a means of addressing two critical needs in the STEM community: the ability to implement successful innovations reliably at scale, and the capacity to organize for and see to its own improvement as a natural embedded aspect of programming. Finally, the project looks to address the problem that fewer than 20 percent of community college enrollees will reach college-level math within three years.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Transforming Students’ Mathematical Experiences: Advancing Quality Teaching (AQT) was a 5-year project to design, test, refine, implement at scale, and sustain professional development focused on instructional improvement in developmental mathematics in a nationwide network of community colleges. This network, the Carnegie Math Pathways (CMP), was established in 2011 to bring together college faculty, administrative leadership, researchers in mathematics education, psychology, and higher education, and improvement specialists to address the devastatingly low success rates and quality of learning in developmental mathematics in community colleges across the country. The approach taken is systemic, involving curriculum design, pedagogical reform, incorporation of social psychological interventions, professional development, support for institutional change, and attention to policy and legislative contexts.

 

The AQT project targeted the professional development component of this effort, and sought to develop, test, and examine professional development models and processes that provided network instructors with the tools necessary to experience efficacy when first teaching Pathways courses, to develop increasing expertise over time, and to engage the larger networked community in research on improving their collective practice. Further, AQT aimed to develop an infrastructure to sustain the implementation, development, and improvement of professional learning opportunities for the Pathways network beyond the period of the grant and as the network scaled dramatically from 10-15 institutions to 80+ institutions. Finally, AQT aimed to contribute to knowledge about the design and implementation of professional development for college mathematics faculty at scale, particularly with respect to how to meet the diverse needs of different kinds of faculty (e.g., full-time, tenure track, adjunct, mathematics, statistics, developmental) to effectively implement a pedagogical model that emphasizes collaborative learning, problem-based teaching, and attention to socio-emotional factors impacting student engagement and learning.

 

A primary efficacy goal of AQT was to support the maintenance of student success outcomes in the network as institutions scaled up. Through the grant period, student outcomes dramatically outperformed comparable students taking alternate mathematics courses, and also demonstrated greater post-course outcomes, including credit accumulation, transfer rates, and 2-year and 4-year graduation rates. These gains remained steady even as the number of enrolled students annually increased seven-fold from approximately 1,500 students to over 10,500 in 2017-18 and the number of instructors teaching increased over five times. In addition, the outcomes from the courses of first-time instructors (a core target of AQT were first-time instructors) who participated in the professional development were not statistically different from the rest of the network.

 

A primary challenge facing AQT was the distributed nature of the network. By the end of the grant period, AQT had reached several hundred math instructors in 100+ colleges and universities and the network is poised to further expand to greater numbers of faculty and institutions. Multiple modalities of access were important for effective faculty engagement and impact. Professional learning opportunities are offered via face-to-face professional development activities delivered multiple times a year in different regions of the country in order to allow for faculty access, particularly for adjunct faculty with limited support and time. Additionally, an online faculty preparation course is offered, which can be taken either in place of a workshop or as a complement. Other online resources that provide deeper dives into specific teaching challenges are offered on a collaborative network website. Finally, a cohort of Faculty Mentors provide one-on-one and team-based support during each faculty member’s first year of teaching. Faculty Mentors are the primary resource for all new faculty and serve as both a coach and a source of just-in-time resources.

 

Several structural features of AQT programs have supported effective implementation at scale. The Faculty Mentor cohort system, with its “train the trainer” model, collaborative design and development of professional learning activities with network faculty, and cultivation of faculty network leadership, is a foundational element of the CMP scaling infrastructure. In addition, Local Faculty Mentors, teams of faculty leadership in instructional improvement at colleges with implementations of the Pathways at large-scale, allow for the extension of the Faculty Mentor model to single campuses. Finally, the organization of the national network into regional sub-networks with associated regional professional development events has allowed AQT to increase the reach of its programs and to make more efficient the delivery of professional development programs through the use of standard “packages” of professional development resources and supports modified for local contexts and that undergo continuous improvement processes.

 

Finally, a significant contribution of AQT is its employing of tools and processes from quality improvement and networked improvement science. A core goal of AQT was to realize the principles of networked improvement communities in the design, implementation, and improvement of professional development. The Faculty Support Program, the largest program within AQT, was designed and iterated utilizing user-centered design approaches, system quality measures, practical measurement processes, and cycles of continuous improvement.
